count_neighbors_by_shell(neighbors_list, alloy_atoms, element_pool)¶

retrun list of dictionary

for each atom the number of nearest neighbor of each type in the first (12) and second (6) shells for fcc

n_neighbours number of first nearest neighbours

return list of dictionanry with number of neighbour of each type

[{'Ag': 4, 'Pd': 8}, # first atom

{'Ag': 6, 'Pd': 6}, # second atom {'Ag': 6, 'Pd': 6}, {'Ag': 8, 'Pd': 4}, {'Ag': 8, 'Pd': 4}, {'Ag': 6, 'Pd': 6}, {'Ag': 6, 'Pd': 6}, {'Ag': 4, 'Pd': 8}] # ....

get_CN_list(shell, alloy_atoms)¶

combinations list of unique pair of atom in the structure symbols_indexes : dictionary with the indexes of each element in the structure return dictionannry with the list of neighbor of each atom by type {'Ag-Ag': [6, 4, 4, 6], # Ag around Ag

'Ag-Pd': [8, 6, 6, 8], # Ag around Pd 'Pd-Ag': [6, 8, 8, 6], 'Pd-Pd': [4, 6, 6, 4]}

structure : pymatgen structure class

return list of numpy array with the neighbors of each site

center_indices, points_indices, offset_vectors, distances 0 1 [ 0. 0. -1.] 2.892 0 2 [ 0. -1. 0.] 2.892 0 5 [ 0. 0. -1.] 2.892 0 6 [ 0. -1. 0.] 2.892 0 4 [-1. 0. 0.] 2.892 0 3 [ 0. 0. -1.] 2.892 0 6 [-1. 0. 0.] 2.892 0 3 [ 0. -1. 0.] 2.892 0 5 [-1. 0. 0.] 2.892 0 4 [0. 0. 0.] 2.892 0 2 [0. 0. 0.] 2.892 0 1 [0. 0. 0.] 2.892

genheas.tools.feedforward module¶

class Feedforward(input_size, output_size)¶

Bases: torch.nn.modules.module.Module

forward(x)¶

Defines the computation performed at every call.

Should be overridden by all subclasses.

Note

Although the recipe for forward pass needs to be defined within this function, one should call the Module instance afterwards instead of this since the former takes care of running the registered hooks while the latter silently ignores them.

multiprocessing_training(workers, AlloyGen, list_networks, list_structures, element_pool, cutoff)¶
plot_optimization(data_filepath, skiprows=1)¶

data_filepath = "training_data/{}a-{}p-{}n-{}m.csv".format(alpha,nb_policies,nb_network_per_policy)

By default we skip the first row, which contains the headers By skipping 2 rows, you can disregard the first data-point (0,0) to get a closer look :param data_filepath: :param skiprows: :return:

train_policy(crystal_structure, element_pool, concentrations, nb_generation, cell_size, cell_param, device='cpu', rate=0.25, alpha=0.1, nn_per_policy=1, nb_policies=8, nb_worker=1, fitness_minimum=0, patience=100, cubik=False, direction=None)¶
Parameters

  • nb_worker --

  • direction --

  • cubik --

  • patience -- (int) nb generations to wait before early stop

  • fitness_minimum -- (float) minimum fitness to reach

  • nb_generation -- (int) number of generation to run

  • nb_policies -- (int) number of policies = input structures

  • nn_per_policy -- (int) number of network per policy

  • alpha -- (float) scaling factor for the weight mutation

  • rate -- (float) % of policy to keep at each generation

  • device -- cpu or gpu

  • cell_param -- (array) lattice constant of the input structure [3.61, 3.61, 3.61]

  • cell_size -- (array) size of the input structure [4,4,4]

  • concentrations -- (dict) concentration of each element {'Ag': 0.5, 'Pd': 0.5}

  • element_pool -- list of element ['Ag', 'Pd']

  • crystal_structure -- (str) 'fcc' 'bcc' 'hpc'

Returns

list with the best weight

genheas.tools.properties module¶

class AtomInitializer(atom_types)¶

Bases: object

Base class for intializing the vector representation for atoms. !!! Use one AtomInitializer per dataset !!!

decode(idx)¶

load_state_dict(state_dict)¶

write_atom_init_json()¶
class AtomJSONInitializer(elem_embedding_file='/home/ctetsass/python/genheas/genheas/tools/data/atom_init.json', rewrite=False)¶

Bases: genheas.tools.properties.AtomInitializer

Initialize atom feature vectors using a JSON file, which is a python dictionary mapping from element number to a list representing the feature vector of the element. :param elem_embedding_file: The path to the .json file :type elem_embedding_file: str
